author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Biden’s Fate Hangs Over Baldwin and Democrats in Congress as Voters Question His Fitness
description: Voters are deeply skeptical about President Biden’s prospects, posing challenges for Senator Tammy Baldwin in Wisconsin and other Democrats once thought to be relatively safe in their seats.
content: Senator Tammy Baldwin, a Wisconsin Democrat seeking re-election, has noticed voters returning to the same question in recent days as she crisscrosses her state to make the case for her campaign: Does she think President Biden can win in November, and should he even try?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe, Katrina Northrop and Eliot Chen
title: 7 Takeaways From Our Investigation Into a Secret Investor in Jack Ma’s Companies
description: Behind the scenes, China’s most celebrated and its most notorious billionaires were linked through investments worth at least $1 billion.
content: No businessman in China was more successful, famous or rich than Jack Ma, whose magic touch turned companies like Alibaba into international juggernauts. He was also unafraid to cross the Chinese authorities, insisting he would not do business with them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Biden Withdraws, Words of Praise and Caution
description: An early sampling of reactions to the president’s announcement.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Biden Made a Courageous Choice. Democrats Must Seize the Opportunity.
description: He did what Trump would never do: place the national interest above his own pride and ambition.
content: President Biden’s decision to exit the 2024 presidential election is a fitting coda for a man whose life has been devoted to public service. Mr. Biden has served the nation well as its president. By agreeing to step down when his term ends in January, he is greatly increasing the chance that his party is able to protect the nation from the dangers of returning Donald Trump to the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Biden Drops His Bid for Re-Election
description: A special edition of The Evening on the president’s decision and what comes next.
content: President Biden abandoned his bid for re-election today, succumbing to intense pressure from the Democratic Party in a dramatic attempt to stop Donald Trump from returning to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik
title: How Kamala Harris Performs Against Donald Trump in the Polls
description: The vice president could enter the general election campaign in a better position than President Biden.
content: After President Biden ended his re-election bid and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris for the Democratic Party’s nomination, questions have turned to her electoral viability — and how she might perform against former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Audra D. S. Burch and Heather Knight
title: Democratic Voters Express Relief and Optimism at Biden’s Announcement
description: Several ardent Democrats said they were grateful to the president for stepping aside and enthusiastic about Kamala Harris as his replacement in the race.
content: Some Democratic voters who have spent the summer wondering whether President Biden would remain in the race reacted with relief and little surprise on Sunday after learning that he would not seek re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: What 4 Key Democratic Governors Have Said About Biden Dropping Out
description: The governors of Pennsylvania, Michigan, California and Illinois have attracted attention as potential contenders to replace President Biden atop the ticket. Here’s what they have said since he dropped out.
content: While Vice President Kamala Harris is at the top of the list of Democrats who could replace President Biden as the party’s nominee for president, earning his endorsement as he dropped out of the race on Sunday, a handful of Democratic governors have also attracted attention as potential presidential contenders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft, Alex Lemonides, Lazaro Gamio and Anna Betts
title: Campus Protests Led to More Than 3,100 Arrests, but Many Charges Have Been Dropped
description: The spate of pro-Palestinian protests and encampments engulfed academic institutions of all sizes in nearly every part of the country.
content: As pro-Palestinian demonstrations rocked college campuses this spring with protests of the war in Gaza, many university administrators found themselves eager to quell the action however they could. Some negotiated with the demonstrators. Many sent in the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: For Fashion, Sports Stars Are the New Superstars
description: Here’s why, and how the balance of power between individual brand and company brand is changing.
content: In the late 1990s, something strange started happening on the cover of glossy magazines. Instead of models, movie stars increasingly became the faces of choice. By 1998, Linda Wells, then the editor of the beauty magazine Allure, announced to her staff, “Nobody cares about models anymore.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: Alex Izenberg Was Almost a Teen Rock Star. His Second Chance Is Here.
description: He was discovered by a star songwriter and hit the road before schizophrenia turned his world upside down. Two decades later, he’s releasing an LP he’d longed to make.
content: On his 12th birthday, in April 2003, Alex Izenberg went to Guitar Center to jam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Mitch Smith and Heather Knight
title: ‘Overjoyed.’ ‘Desperate.’ ‘Too Late.’ Democrats React to Biden’s Exit
description: Democratic voters said they were relieved that President Biden was ending his campaign, but many said they remain worried about the political path ahead.
content: For Democratic voters who have spent much of the summer brooding about President Biden’s fitness for office, his decision on Sunday not to seek re-election came as a  relief. Now, they figured, their political party might stand a chance in November — though many still expressed deep doubts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: After a Shaky Start, Harris Is Suddenly on Brink of Leading Democratic Ticket
description: Vice President Kamala Harris got off to a rocky start in office. She is now at the heart of a political drama that could make her the first woman of color to become a major party presidential nominee.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris, who has struggled for nearly four years in President Biden’s shadow, was thrust on Sunday into the center of a remarkable political drama that could culminate with her becoming the first woman of color at the top of a major-party presidential ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Sorkin
title: Aaron Sorkin: How I Would Script This Moment for Biden and the Democrats
description: What would President Bartlet do?
content: Update: Joe Biden announced on Sunday that he would not seek re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabby Sobelman and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Israel Intercepts Missile Fired From Yemen as Conflict With Houthis Continues
description: The missile launch suggested that the Yemen-based Houthi militia, which is backed by Iran, would keep up its attacks despite Israeli airstrikes on a port it controls.
content: Israel’s military said on Sunday that it had intercepted a missile fired from Yemen, suggesting that the Yemen-based Houthi militia would keep trying to strike Israel, despite the bombing by Israeli fighter jets of a port in Yemen on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: If Kamala Harris Is a D.E.I. Candidate, So Is JD Vance
description: He benefited from one of the most powerful forms of affirmative action that elite universities practice.
content: Ever since speculation began that Vice President Kamala Harris might replace President Biden at the top of the Democratic ticket, there has been a steady, ugly chorus on the right. The New York Post published a column that declared that Harris would be a “D.E.I. president,” and quickly the phrase ricocheted across the conservative media ecosystem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong’s Bouncy ‘Wonders’ Leave Some Wondering, ‘Why?’
description: Inflatable replicas of famous monuments popped up in a park, raising questions about art and Hong Kong’s changing place in the world.
content: With darkness falling along Hong Kong’s waterfront against a backdrop of glimmering skyscrapers, carnival music competed with the whine of ventilation blowers as visitors bounced on the inflatable Stonehenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Simon J. Levien
title: A Week After Shooting, Trump Leaves Unity Behind and Returns to Insults and Election Denial
description: A week after an assassination attempt led him to call for unity, former President Donald J. Trump returned to the campaign trail, lashing out at his rivals and claiming persecution.
content: At his first campaign rally since he survived an assassination attempt last week, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday launched a litany of attacks that suggested his call for national unity in the wake of the shooting had faded entirely into the background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: A Harris Economy Could Prove More Progressive Than ‘Bidenomics’
description: As a presidential candidate in the past, the former California senator pushed for higher taxes and bigger housing investments.
content: At the first Democratic presidential debate in 2019, Kamala Harris, then a senator from California, unleashed a scathing critique of the Trump economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Where Kamala Harris Stands on the Issues: Abortion, Immigration and More
description: She wants to protect the right to abortion nationally. Here’s what else to know about her positions.
content: With Vice President Kamala Harris being eyed as a potential replacement for President Biden on the Democratic ticket, her stances on key issues will be scrutinized by both parties and the nation’s voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: The World’s Most Fashionable Judoka Is Looking for Clothes in His Size
description: Teddy Riner has long had trouble finding stylish apparel for his 6-foot-8 frame. Could it be time to create his own line?
content: If you’re 6-foot-8 and 300 pounds, it can be hard to find fashionable clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: A Critical Gap in Democracy? ‘Yawn,’ Say Canadian Politicians.
description: China and India have been accused of exploiting the opaque nomination contests of Canadian political parties to meddle in elections.
content: It is the “Wild West” of Canada’s political system, a “critical gap” in its democracy. But Canadian political leaders — and some foreign nations — are big fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Jennifer Medina
title: How Will Democrats Replace Biden at the Top of the Presidential Ticket?
description: The president cleared the way for a successor. He endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris, but there could still be a contest to determine who the nominee will be.
content: Now that President Biden has withdrawn from the presidential race, the question facing the Democratic Party is no longer whether he can be replaced at the top of the ticket. It is how to do it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: At a rally, Trump jeered at the Democratic Party’s infighting. Here’s the latest.
description: Former Pr
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, fresh off his nominating convention and all of the exposure that came with it, held a boisterous rally in Grand Rapids, Mich., on Saturday, the first with his new running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, and his first since an assassination attempt against him just over a week ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Holmes
title: Thanks, but No Thanks
description: If a lunch with your boss makes you feel uncomfortable, you don’t have to go. Suggest an alternative.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim and Shuaib Almosawa
title: Israeli Strike on Yemeni Port Will Harm Civilians, Not Houthis, Experts Say
description: Israel’s counterattack on the Houthis, which set a vital Yemeni port ablaze, will do little to deter the militia, Yemeni and international experts said.
content: The Israeli bombing of a vital Yemeni port controlled by the Houthi militia is not expected to deter the group from further attacks but is likely to deepen human suffering in Yemen, regional experts said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Cars, but Make It Fashion
description: Ferrari has positioned itself as a high-end fashion and lifestyle brand that appeals to more than just Formula 1 fans. Could Jeep follow that lead?
content: Ferrari is more than just a car company — it’s a lifestyle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat
title: Bangladesh Scales Back Policy on Public-Sector Hiring That Sparked Unrest
description: A court ruling has sharply reduced a quota system for filling government jobs, after protests over the issue turned violent and were brutally suppressed.
content: The Supreme Court of Bangladesh on Sunday drastically reduced the number of government jobs reserved for war veterans and their descendants, a momentous decision spurred by violent student protests that had resulted in the deaths of more than 100 people and brought the country to a standstill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Erica L. Green and Nicholas Nehamas
title: What’s Next for the Harris Campaign
description: Vice President Kamala Harris faces many questions, from the management of her campaign to the selection of her running mate, should she be the Democratic Party’s nominee.
content: President Biden endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris to lead the presidential ticket after ending his re-election campaign on Sunday, raising the chance that she could be the first Black woman and the first person of Indian descent to be president of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley and Thalassa Raasch and Damon Winter
title: The Meaning of Prayer at a Political Convention
description: Prayers at events such as the Republican National Convention can take on the feel of a religious veneer for certain policies.
content: As an Anglican clergy member, I have prayed for political leaders as a regular feature of my life. Each Sunday, at the church I attend with my family, we have a moment set aside to remember those who have political power. These intercessions are not declarations of policy agreement. I have prayed publicly for George W. Bush, Barack Obama, Donald Trump and Joe Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The Misfit Wisdom of Harry, Barry and Larry
description: Harry Crews, Barry Hannah and Larry Brown were part of a Southern writers’ movement that centered dissidents and outsiders. They’re still worth reading.
content: In and around Oxford, Miss., about three decades ago, it wasn’t uncommon to drive along a rural route and pass a car with a bumper sticker that said, “I’d rather be reading Airships.” The people in those cars tended to have their windows rolled down, and they looked awfully happy. These were the kind of free and literate souls, with their muddy boots and eyeglasses, that a bar-stool sociologist might call liberal rednecks. Someone slapped a copy of that bumper sticker on William Faulkner’s grave in Oxford. No one thought it vandalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Drops Out of Race, Scrambling the Campaign for the White House
description: The president’s withdrawal under pressure from fellow Democrats cleared the way for a new nominee to take on former President Donald J. Trump in the fall. He quickly endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris.
content: President Biden on Sunday abruptly abandoned his campaign for a second term under intense pressure from fellow Democrats and threw his support to Vice President Kamala Harris to lead their party in a dramatic last-minute bid to stop former President Donald J. Trump from returning to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Dan Simmons and Christina Morales
title: How Undecided Voters Are Responding to Biden Dropping Out
description: Many who had been dissatisfied with their choices now face a whole new race — and a new set of questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Sean Kingston and His Mother Are Indicted in $1 Million Fraud Scheme
description: Mr. Kingston, who is best known for his 2007 hit single “Beautiful Girls,” and his mother were charged with defrauding sellers of high-end vehicles, jewelry and other goods, prosecutors said.
content: The singer and rapper Sean Kingston and his mother have been indicted in Florida on federal charges related to a scheme in which they committed more than $1 million worth of fraud, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Democratic Elites Were Slow to See What Voters Already Knew
description: Be skeptical when you hear that this is all a plot.
content: President Biden and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez agree on this much: It is the elites who are trying to take Biden down, ignoring the sentiments of legions of Democratic voters. But when I started arguing in February that his age would mortally wound his candidacy, it didn’t feel that way to me. I saw the elites propping him up, ignoring the sentiments of legions of Democratic voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Kuhlman
title: I Was a White House Doctor. Presidents Should Have to Take Cognitive Tests.
description: We need to rethink how we assess and evaluate physical and mental fitness for the presidency.
content: The job of president is physically and mentally demanding. I witnessed this firsthand as a White House physician for three presidents, including as the designated physician to the president for Barack Obama during his first term. My presidential patients often worked 12-hour days seven days a week. The leader of the free world travels constantly, and participates in or leads briefings in which he must retain huge amounts of information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Utah Officials Backtrack on Untested Execution Drug
description: An execution, scheduled for next month, would have used an experimental three-drug combination that critics said could inflict serious pain.
content: Plans to use an experimental three-drug combination in an upcoming execution in Utah — a cocktail that critics said could inflict serious pain — have been scrapped after state officials said in court documents released Saturday that they would be able to seek an alternative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: What Joe Biden Just Did Is Utterly Extraordinary
description: It’s hard to grasp the historical rarity, emotional agony and fundamental humility of what the president just did.
content: In the hours and days to come, many political observers will say that President Biden was backed into a corner and had no choice but to end his re-election campaign. His limitations had been laid painfully bare. He’d lost the confidence of the Democratic Party. And he was staggering toward an increasingly ugly revolt within it or a potentially harrowing defeat by Donald Trump. Bowing out wasn’t an act of grace. It was a saving of face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Tadej Pogacar Returns to the Top, Winning the Tour de France
description: Pogacar won his third Tour, beating his rival Jonas Vingegaard by 6:17 after a final time trial victory in Nice on Sunday.
content: When an athlete wins a championship two years in a row, but then slips to second the next two years, it’s fair to assume that he may be starting a downswing — that he is a cut below the new champion and that he will struggle to beat him in the years ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Kamala Harris or Bust
description: The only conversation the Democrats need to be having now is about how to line up behind their vice president.
content: President Biden’s decision to withdraw was probably a foregone conclusion a week ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Manchin Calls for Biden to Withdraw His Candidacy
description: Senator Joe Manchin III, an independent from West Virginia who caucuses with Democrats, is the fifth senator aligned with the party to urge President Biden not to seek re-election.
content: Senator Joe Manchin III, a longtime Democrat from West Virginia who recently abandoned the party to declare himself an independent, on Sunday joined the growing calls in the Senate for President Biden to step aside as the Democratic nominee for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Truman and Johnson Also Stepped Aside, but ‘the Circumstances Are Quite Different’
description: The candidates who secured the Democratic nomination after the two presidents dropped out would go on to lose the election. But historians say political history doesn’t necessarily repeat itself.
content: In the last 75 years, only two Democratic presidents, Harry S. Truman and Lyndon B. Johnson, decided during an election year not to run again, surprising the nation by announcing that they would allow fresh candidates to vie for their party’s nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 21, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 21, 2024.
content: A picture caption with an article on July 7 about Taylor Swift misstated the year of the Billboard Hot 100 when the Beatles held the top five spots. It was the week of April 4, 1964, not 1962.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Isaac-Goizé
title: The Kingmakers
description: The French agency L’AM specializes in connecting elite athletes with luxury fashion brands.
content: This spring, after attending the Dior show during Paris Fashion Week, the fencer and Olympic silver medalist Sara Balzer was announced as an ambassador for the brand. The following month, she appeared on the cover of French Elle alongside Pauline Déroulède, a wheelchair tennis player, and Marie Patouillet, a para-cyclist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: On TikTok, True Crime Survivors Take Control
description: The genre is wildly popular across media, but often produced without input from those most affected. Viral videos are helping survivors own their stories.
content: On Feb. 9, 2004, Maura Murray went missing on Route 112 in Haverhill, N.H., after a string of puzzling events. A neighbor who witnessed a single-car crash reported it to the police. When officers showed up, Murray’s car was locked and she was nowhere to be found. She hasn’t been seen since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das
title: Behind Bangladesh Protests, Rage Over Inequality
description: Demonstrations set off by the reinstatement of a quota system for government jobs revealed broader resentment about the uneven distribution of wealth and opportunity.
content: The video, taken this month, shows a Bangladeshi protester wearing a black T-shirt and standing on one side of an empty street. His arms are outstretched, and he is holding a stick in one hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing: Biden Ends His Re-Election Bid
description: The president endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris to continue the race against Donald Trump.
content: President Biden abandoned his bid for re-election yesterday, succumbing to intense pressure from the Democratic Party in a dramatic attempt to stop Donald Trump from returning to the White House. No sitting U.S. president has dropped out of a race so late in an election cycle. Follow our live coverage of reactions, endorsements and further developments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: Answers to Questions From Morning Readers
description: Times journalists from around the newsroom talk about their beats and our work.
content: The Morning recently invited its readers to submit questions. Below, we’re publishing a selection of them, along with answers from Times staff members. (We also published some answers in today’s edition of The Morning.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Twisters’ Takes Off at the Box Office
description: The disaster movie was on pace to sell roughly $80 million in tickets in North America over the weekend, 60 percent more than expected.
content: So much for those theories about moviegoers being hungry for original stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Could This Van Help People Quit Fentanyl?
description: Methadone has been used for decades to treat opioid addiction. It is also difficult to come by, a problem health providers hope to ease with a new fleet of vans that can provide the drug.
content: Before he started taking methadone, Vinny Parisi had overdosed 16 times from using street drugs, including fentanyl. Eating out of garbage cans and sleeping under a bridge in Harlem, he finally hit bottom, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Roasted Salmon With Peas and Radishes, Hasselback Kielbasa With Jalapeño Honey
description: Cook whatever you want to cook, however you want to cook it, without judgment.
content: Good morning. Real talk on a Sunday: “Foodie” is a smug, unpleasant word, a diminutive, patronizing expression that reduces a person’s keen interest in the delicious to a silly fascination with cooking and eating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Can Kamala Harris Step Up? Asking for a Friend.
description: What are the alternatives? And about those Republicans …
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, these have been some very difficult days. I’ve been thinking of you a lot but maybe we should go to politics first. President Biden is out. Where is Howard Cosell when you need him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Democratic Billionaires and Donors Rush to Back Harris After Biden’s Exit
description: Advisers and major givers said they were being inundated with enthusiasm and plans for donations to support Ms. Harris if she won the nomination.
content: Democratic donors are immediately mobilizing around Kamala Harris as their party’s next presidential nominee, offering Democratic elites something they have not felt in weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: With Biden Out, Vice President Kamala Harris Has a Chance to Make History Again
description: Ms. Harris, the first woman, and woman of color, to be vice president, has faced sexist and racist attacks, but she has energized a network of support.
content: President Biden’s decision to drop out of the 2024 presidential race and endorse Vice President Kamala Harris to be the new Democratic nominee gives Ms. Harris, already the first woman, and woman of color, to be vice president, another opportunity to make history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley
title: China Shows Few Signs of Tilting Economy Toward Consumers in New Plan
description: The Communist Party rebuffed calls from economists to shift away from investment-led growth and toward consumer spending.
content: China engaged in a monthslong drumbeat of anticipation that a Communist Party leaders’ meeting would show the way to a new era of growth for the slowing economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: How Two Wandering Cows Started a Culture War
description: When Hornee and Blackee strayed from their pasture, they set off a chaotic chain of events involving death threats, chicken rustlers and Joaquin Phoenix. The town of Newfane, N.Y., hasn’t been the same since.
content: One summer day, a cow and a steer walked away from their farm. The cow was black and was named Blackee. The steer was golden brown, with two stubby horns. He was named Hornee. Nobody knows when the cows got out, or how. They crossed a field and a road and wandered onto a neighbor’s yard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: From Naples to New Orleans, Murder and Mayhem
description: Our crime columnist on four new novels.
content: This month’s column is all about firsts — debut authors, new series beginnings or both. I make it a point to pick up books by new authors whenever I can. Sure, there’s pleasure to be had in discovering someone 10 books into a series and binge-reading them all, but I like embracing promising careers at the ground level, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Kamala Harris Says She’s Running in Biden’s Place
description: The vice president said that she was honored by President Biden’s endorsement, and that she intended to “earn and win” the Democratic nomination.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris announced on Sunday that she would seek the nomination of the Democratic Party after President Biden said he would withdraw from the race and endorsed her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe, Katrina Northrop and Eliot Chen
title: The Billionaire Criminal Who Secretly Profited Off Jack Ma’s Deals
description: Confidential documents show that Xiao Jianhua, a corrupt investor tied to China’s political elite, backed the country’s most successful and revered entrepreneur.
content: Four years ago, Jack Ma was the embodiment of China’s spectacular economic rise. Already the country’s wealthiest and most famous businessman, he was poised to become one of the richest in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: World Leaders, With Outlook Uncertain, Praise Biden but Speak Carefully
description: Foreign leaders did not wade into the turmoil of U.S. politics. Many opted instead for statements of empathy that lauded the president’s record.
content: Some were valedictory, praising an American president’s legacy. Others lauded the courage they said it took to walk away from power. But a few world leaders struck another note over President Biden’s decision not to seek re-election: trepidation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Ulrich
title: Corvette Bucked a Sports Cars Decline. Can It Thrive in an E.V. Era?
description: The General Motors sports car, which enjoyed strong sales after a big design change, now has a hybrid version and may get a fully electric model that may turn off some gas-loving customers.
content: Sales of sports cars have been steadily declining for about three decades, but there has been one exception to that trend. The Chevrolet Corvette has recently stormed back to near-record popularity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,129, Monday, July 22, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: ‘Love Island USA’ Finds Its Magic Formula for Success
description: A new host, an embrace of social media and some excellent casting led to the former also-ran becoming the summer’s buzziest show.
content: There is no shortage of dating reality shows, but this summer one is receiving the majority of the buzz. “Love Island USA,” an American spinoff of a popular British dating show, is dominating social media discourse, breaking streaming records and making fans out of even the most curmudgeonly anti-reality TV watchers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and Albert Sun
title: Trump’s Conviction and Biden’s Poor Debate Sent Big Money Into the Race
description: The Biden campaign also spent six times as much as the Trump campaign did in June, allowing Republicans to gain a financial advantage.
content: A pair of seismic events in May and June unleashed gushers of money into the presidential fund-raising race — and that was before an assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: With Biden Out, What Happens Next? Here’s What We Know.
description: Democrats are gaming out scenarios, some of them more likely than others. One thing is clear: Kamala Harris has the inside lane.
content: Now that President Biden has ended his re-election bid, Democrats must choose a replacement nominee in less than a month, condensing what is typically a yearlong primary campaign into just a couple weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Isadora Kosofsky
title: Eight Decades Later, a Celebration of Faith Renewed
description: More than 50,000 American Catholics gathered at the first National Eucharistic Congress since the 1940s.
content: Lucas Oil Stadium, the vast brick home to the Indianapolis Colts, is space custom-built for commotion and cacophony. On Wednesday night, the seats were mostly filled, families having shuffled into rows balancing paper trays of chicken fingers and pizza. But at 7 p.m., the lights went down, and the crowd sat poised in stillness and silence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Judge Rejects Bid to Dismiss Trump Libel Suit Against Pulitzer Board
description: Donald Trump sued the Pulitzer Prize Board over its 2022 statement reaffirming its decision to award a prize for coverage of the 2016 Trump campaign’s ties to Russia.
content: A state judge in Florida has given former President Donald J. Trump a legal victory, refusing to toss a libel lawsuit filed by Mr. Trump over a statement made by the board of the Pulitzer Prizes on coverage of the 2016 Trump campaign’s connections to Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: You Ask, We Answer
description: We’re answering reader questions about this newsletter, and the news in general.
content: We recently asked you — the readers of The Morning — to submit questions to us about this newsletter, recent news or anything else on your minds. We’re devoting today’s edition to some of your questions and our answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: On the Trail With Trump, Vance Shows He Knows His Place: Offstage, Mostly
description: JD Vance, the Republican nominee for vice president, was a mere warm-up act to Donald J. Trump at their first joint rally.
content: It was his first campaign rally as Donald J. Trump’s running mate, and JD Vance was up onstage, all by his lonesome, playing it humble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: For LVMH, the Olympics Are Welcome, but Not Without Risk
description: The reaction to the conglomerate’s involvement in the Games has been relatively — and surprisingly — free of criticism, yet the stakes are high.
content: Among the dozens of sponsors of this summer’s Olympic and Paralympic Games in Paris, one will be by far the most visible and influential: LVMH, the French luxury goods conglomerate. The company has invested 150 million euros ($163 million) in the 2024 Olympic Games, a gamble for a brand that has long marketed its goods to the upper echelons of society. And the company isn’t just putting its name on the event. It is putting its products … well, pretty much everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers, Michael D. Shear, Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Inside the Weekend When Biden Decided to Withdraw
description: President Biden did not tell most of his staff until a minute before making his announcement to the world on social media on Sunday. Vice President Kamala Harris, whom Mr. Biden went on to endorse, also learned of his decision on Sunday.
content: “I need you and Mike at the house,” President Biden said late Saturday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: A Lost Opera Returns, and Shouldn’t Be Lost Again
description: Teatro Nuovo is giving Carolina Uccelli’s pioneering “Anna di Resburgo” its first performances since its premiere in 1835.
content: Luck has a lot to do with legacy in music, and Carolina Uccelli didn’t have much of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: After Biden Drops Out, Trump Says He Was ‘Never’ Fit to Be President
description: In his first statement since President Biden dropped out of the race, the former president accused Democrats of covering up concerns about Biden’s age.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump seized on President Biden’s decision to end his bid for re-election, saying he had never been fit to serve — an attack on his former rival that was immediately followed by other Republicans calling on the president to step down from office as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For Biden, a Decision to Step Aside Would Raise Another Question
description: As President Biden grapples with the possibility of dropping his bid for re-election, a secondary question looms: Should he endorse his own vice president as the nominee?
content: President Biden has been saying some awfully nice things about Vice President Kamala Harris lately. “She’s not only a great vice president,” he told the audience at an N.A.A.C.P. convention last week. “She could be president of the United States.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Inside the ‘Gangster’ Image of Donald Trump
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has an aggressive — and some argue offensive — campaign using hip-hop and rap to reach young Black and Latino voters.
content: Amber Rose, an OnlyFans model, influencer and former girlfriend to rappers, took the stage at the Republican National Convention on Monday night sporting her platinum buzz cut and face tattoo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Shane Goldmacher
title: Can Harris Inherit Biden’s Campaign Cash? Most Likely, Yes.
description: “In my view, this is not an open question,” said one Federal Election Commission member. But Republicans are likely to try to block the transfer.
content: It’s the $96 million question: Can Vice President Kamala Harris seamlessly inherit the huge sum of money that President Biden amassed in his war chest for the Biden-Harris ticket?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: One of the Republican Convention’s Weirdest Lies
description: It was one long exercise in creating memories of a Trump term that never existed.
content: I watched hour upon hour of the Republican National Convention, something I’ve done every four years since I was a young political nerd in 1984. I was even a Mitt Romney delegate at the Republican convention in 2012, and this was the first that revolved entirely around a fundamentally false premise: that in our troubled time, Donald Trump would be a source of order and stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Vanhoenacker
title: Have a Foreign Language Love Affair This Summer
description: Have translation tools made learning a language pointless? Not a chance.
content: One morning late last autumn, I took off from London’s Heathrow Airport, my base as a Boeing 787 pilot, and landed the next morning at Haneda Airport in Tokyo. By early afternoon I was walking under the turning foliage of Rikugien, one of my favorite gardens, where I paused by a wooden sign at the edge of a stream. Despite having studied Japanese for years, the text on the sign — something about slippery stones ahead — included several characters I didn’t recognize, so I fired up an app I’d recently discovered. It scanned and translated all of them instantly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Amanda Holpuch
title: Pacific Northwest Faces Critical Fire Risk as Wildfires Burn
description: More than half a million people were under fire danger warnings on Sunday as a heat wave hit the region and several large blazes burned in Oregon.
content: A dangerous heat wave, gusty winds and potential lightning strikes posed a critical fire risk for large parts of the Pacific Northwest on Sunday, as firefighters in Oregon and Washington battled wildfires that have burned more than 621,000 acres.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: On Your Marks, Get Set, Serve!
description: Waiters in London competed in an annual footrace designed to test their mettle, their coordination and their skill as servers.
content: An expert waiter is both gymnast and poet. One’s a fast talker with fancy footwork and a steel-trap memory. Another can dodge a pushed-back chair, martini high overhead, without spilling a drop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Biden and Georgia Are Waging a Fight Over Medicaid and the Future of Obamacare
description: A fierce battle with Georgia over a Medicaid experiment with stricter enrollment underscores the vast divide between parties over how to cover lower-income Americans.
content: The Affordable Care Act was once a potent electoral issue that could swing campaigns with its more familiar moniker, Obamacare. But the 2010 health law did not factor into last week’s Republican National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Methadone Vans Aim to Bring Help Closer to Addicts
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 21, 2024.
content: “My mother sent me a picture of me and 12 friends, and I’m the only one left alive.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Clintons Endorse Kamala Harris to Be Democrats’ Nominee for President
description: The former president and the former secretary of state swiftly backed Vice President Kamala Harris to replace President Biden atop the Democratic ticket.
content: Former President Bill Clinton and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton posted a statement on social media on Sunday afternoon endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris to take President Biden’s place as the party’s nominee for November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Democrats Donate More Than $50 Million Online After Biden’s Exit
description: Sunday was the single biggest day for online Democratic donations in years — a significant show of enthusiasm after weeks of sluggish fund-raising.
content: Democrats greeted President Biden’s departure from the presidential race with an avalanche of cash, donating more than $50 million online on Sunday and making it the single biggest day for online Democratic contributions since the 2020 election — with hours to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: The Northwest Bakes Again, but Relief May Be Coming for Some Areas
description: After a blistering weekend, particularly in inland areas farther from the coast, cooler temperatures are expected beginning early this week.
content: A heat wave that brought dangerously high temperatures near 110 degrees to some inland parts of Washington, Oregon and Idaho this weekend is forecast to recede for some areas early this week — but not in Boise, Idaho, where Sunday’s high of 108 degrees broke the daily record.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was Settling Into My Morning Commute on the 4 Train’
description: Catching up on the news, appreciating a counterman’s skills and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Antisemitism on Campuses, Ivy and Beyond
description: Responses to a column by Bret Stephens. Also: Pharmacy benefit managers; the Supreme Court; a potential second Trump term and the environment.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 407, July 22, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read Biden’s Letter Withdrawing From the Race
description: President Biden announced on social media that he was abandoning his re-election bid.
content: President Biden announced on social media that he was abandoning his re-election bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe, Karen Hanley and Laura Salaberry
title: Behind Our Reporting on a Secret Investor in Jack Ma’s Companies
description: Confidential documents show that Xiao Jianhua, a corrupt investor tied to China’s political elite, backed Ma, the country’s most successful and revered entrepreneur.
content: Confidential documents show that Xiao Jianhua, a corrupt investor tied to China’s political elite, backed Ma, the country’s most successful and revered entrepreneur.
source.name: The New York Times
